column1: CDCEmergency

The CDC network that tracks #COVID19 hospitalization rates shows overall hospitalization rate increasing, w/ rates increasing w/ age. Rates in ppl 65+ are highest at 39 per 100,000 people. Ppl 65+ should take special precautions to prevent COVID-19. https://bit.ly/2WdYQ8I pic.twitter.com/NGaD1dgvHK

Employers: CDC recommends add’l precautions in workplaces carrying out critical functions to protect workers & communities. An employer’s #COVID19 toolkit should include pre-screening, regular monitoring, wearing masks, social distance, & disinfection. https://bit.ly/2Vf16u pic.twitter.com/iwbhhHg30R

If you are 65 or older, you are at higher risk for getting seriously ill from #coronavirus. Learn how you can take steps to protect yourself and slow the spread at http://coronavirus.gov . #COVID19pic.twitter.com/C1W6gbmbpZ

New @CDCMMWR report highlights geographic differences in COVID-19 cases and deaths in the U.S. Learn more about the factors that are likely contributing to these differences and how communities can use these data to reduce the spread of COVID-19: https://bit.ly/MMWR_COVID19Geography ….pic.twitter.com/ygPHko9tGJ

Is your partner or child sick with #COVID19? Know their doctor’s number. Treat symptoms with lots of fluids & over-the-counter medicines. Make sure they rest. If possible, have them stay in a separate room. Learn more about caring for someone who’s sick: https://bit.ly/3a5uKZo .pic.twitter.com/K48Cm6pTvG
.@CDCDirector has extended the March 14 cruise ship No Sail Order to prevent the spread of #COVID19 among cruise ship passengers and crew. See the latest update:pic.twitter.com/SZ8tatKBQq

New COVIDView reports hospitalization rates and deaths from #COVID19 are increasing. Indicators that track hospitalizations and deaths usually lag behind indicators that track illness. https://bit.ly/2ViFflZ pic.twitter.com/wPTwIVFQF5

Most people who get #COVID19 will get better at home. If you are caring for someone who is sick:
• Have the person stay in a separate room & use a separate bathroom (if possible).
• Check how they are feeling but limit face-to-face contact.

More tips: https://bit.ly/3a5uKZo pic.twitter.com/kGlQNCMRmV

#DYK? CDC’s recommendation on wearing a cloth face covering may help protect the most vulnerable from #COVID19. Watch @Surgeon_General Jerome Adams make a face covering in a few easy steps.pic.twitter.com/w3ZlMQgCg3

Help stop the domino chain of #COVID19 infection. Stay home. Wash your hands. When out for essential trips, wear a cloth face covering, and keep at least 6 feet of distance between yourself and others. https://bit.ly/3aVQc3g pic.twitter.com/R6CTRrTn24

Ask CDC: Will taking anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen worsen symptoms of COVID-19?  
Dr. John Brooks, CDC’s Chief Medical Officer for the COVID-19 emergency response, explains what is known about anti-inflammatory drugs and coronavirus.pic.twitter.com/rADViSTwmL
Important information from @CDCgov on how to prepare for unpredictable spring weather, including #tornadoes and #floods: http://ow.ly/e3Qx50z8k2m  #PrepYourHealth
Thank you to all the healthcare workers who are fighting #COVID19. For detailed resources to guide you as you keep our communities safe, see: https://bit.ly/33UUNA2  #NPHWpic.twitter.com/wFfQVxFCgP

Do you have friends or family who need #COVID19 information in a different language? @CDCgov's COVID-19 website has options in Spanish, simplified Chinese, Vietnamese, & Korean. Be sure to look for links to other languages. http://cdc.gov/coronavirus pic.twitter.com/CsONgxZ86W

To slow the spread of #COVID19, stay at home except to get groceries, medications, or other essentials. Avoid outings you don’t have to take. Learn how to protect yourself when running errands: http://ow.ly/mBlw30qwq1d  #PhysicalDistance #SocialDistancingpic.twitter.com/SBKALDmlrg

Wearing a cloth face covering CORRECTLY can help prevent the spread of #COVID19 to others. When you go out on essential trips, follow these “do’s”. If you have a child, remember those under age 2 should not wear a face covering. See https://bit.ly/2R9av5m .pic.twitter.com/0mUIoeA9aS

Looking for indoor activities to engage & educate children? See #ReadyWrigley materials from @CDCemergency. Download & share these resources, including activity books on topics like winter weather, hurricane, & tornado preparedness: http://ow.ly/Y8d730qrpdl  #PrepYourHealth #NPHWpic.twitter.com/vAyw3ooEyi

It’s National Public Health Week (#NPHW). There has never been a more fitting time to acknowledge the work of public health & healthcare professionals than during the COVID-19 pandemic. The nation’s health is PUBLIC HEALTH.pic.twitter.com/K4phkgtxJc

Employers of essential critical workers exposed to #COVID19:
• Take employee’s temperature before work
• Send sick employees home immediately
• Test face masks
• Increase building’s air exchange
• Clean surfaces frequently 
https://bit.ly/2Vf16uh pic.twitter.com/8TlpIzzmcC

Is someone in your home sick with #COVID19?  Do not clean the area around them unless it is soiled. In the rest of the home, clean often touched surfaces & objects (phones, tables, countertops, light switches, doorknobs) using soap & water then disinfect. https://bit.ly/2RiCLD1 pic.twitter.com/sFqMrREzYJ
